title.definition: The <title> tag is required in all HTML documents and it defines the title of the document.
title.usage: defines a title in the browser toolbar /n provides a title for the page when it is added to favorites /n displays a title for the page in search-engine results

article.definition: The <article> tag specifies independent, self-contained content.
article.usage: An article should make sense on its own and it should be possible to distribute it independently from the rest of the site.

head.definition: The <head> element is a container for metadata (data about data) and is placed between the <html> tag and the <body> tag.
head.usage: HTML metadata is data about the HTML document. Metadata is not displayed.

style.definition: The <style> tag is used to define style information for an HTML document.
style.usage: Inside the <style> element you specify how HTML elements should render in a browser

footer.definition: The <footer> tag defines a footer for a document or section..
footer.usage: A <footer> element should contain information about its containing element.

nav.definition: The <nav> tag defines a set of navigation links.
nav.usage: Notice that NOT all links of a document should be inside a <nav> element. The <nav> element is intended only for major block of navigation links.

span.definition: The <span> tag is used to group inline-elements in a document .
span.usage: The <span> tag provides a way to add a hook to a part of a text or a part of a document.

li.definition: The <li> tag defines a list item.
li.usage: The <li> tag is used in ordered lists(<ol>), unordered lists (<ul>), and in menu lists (<menu>).

div.definition: The <div> tag defines a division or a section in an HTML document.
div.usage: The <div> element is often used as a container for other HTML elements to style them with CSS or to perform certain tasks with JavaScript.

button.definition: The <button> tag defines a clickable button.
button.usage: Inside a <button> element you can put content, like text or images. This is the difference between this element and buttons created with the <input> element
